docs.abstract: Electronic Privacy Information Center international review of encryption policies finds governments around world are relaxing controls on technology used to scramble computer communications and keep them secure; finds trend is coupled with attempts by law enforcement authorities to gain new surveillance powers; sees efforts raising new legal questions (M)

headline.main: Some Countries Seek Keys to Digital Code-Scramblers

docs.lead_paragraph: Governments around the world are relaxing their controls on the technology used to scramble computer communications and keep them secure. But according to a survey to be released on Monday, that trend is coupled with attempts by law enforcement authorities to gain new surveillance powers. The report is the third international review of encryption policies by the Electronic Privacy Information Center, a public interest research group in Washington. The study (www2.epic.org/reports/crypto2000) finds that many countries have abandoned earlier attempts to require that a third-party escrow agent be given a spare key to an encryption code as a condition for loosening government controls.
docs.snippet: Governments around the world are relaxing their controls on the technology used to scramble computer communications and keep them secure. But according to a survey to be released on Monday, that trend is coupled with attempts by law enforcement au...

headline.main: Can Microsoft Make Its Mark On the Web?

docs.lead_paragraph: Microsoft trails America Online so badly in the online business that some industry experts say it should stick to its software knitting and end its ill-starred march into cyberspace. Instead, Microsoft is redoubling its efforts. The formula will be the same, roughly, as the one the company followed with its come-from-behind winners, the Office productivity suite and the Internet Explorer browser. The recipe: competitive products, aggressive marketing and pricing.
docs.snippet: Microsoft trails America Online so badly in the online business that some industry experts say it should stick to its software knitting and end its ill-starred march into cyberspace.    Instead, Microsoft is redoubling its efforts. The formula wil...

docs.abstract: About 28,000 tons of genetically modified corn, StarLink, was imported from United States and used in Japan this year; corn has not been approved for human consumption in either country or for any use in Japan; approval of Star Link, developed by Aventis CropScience, for human consumption has been held up by questions about possible allergic reactions (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: About 28,000 tons of a genetically modified corn, StarLink, was imported from the United States and used in food in Japan this year, health officials said Thursday. The corn has not been approved for human consumption in either country or for any use in Japan. There were no reports of ill effects from people who consumed food or beer made with the corn, Akira Miki, a health ministry official, said.

docs.abstract: Palm Inc, whose hand-held computers became icon for popular technology boom, tells attendees at Palmsource conference that it is gradually retooling its business model to counter competition fashioned primarily by its own success; photo (M)

headline.main: Palm Urges Solidarity as Competitors Gain

docs.lead_paragraph: Palm Inc., whose hand-held computers became an icon for the popular- technology boom, is gradually retooling its business model to counter competition fashioned primarily by its own success. The strategy shift has become clear here at the PalmSource conference, where 3,000 developers of programs that run on Palm's operating system came to hear the company's vision for the future. Even as they discussed their plans to barrel into the wireless Internet and corporate markets, executives here made their bottom-line message clear: Circle the wagons around the Palm operating system, uniting against an assault led by the Pocket PC operating system from Microsoft.

docs.abstract: 3Com says its second quarter loss will be greater than anticipated; stock's price falls to $9.75 from $13.38 (M)

headline.main: 3Com Says Its Losses Will Exceed Expectations; Shares Drop

docs.lead_paragraph: Asserting it had been battered by turmoil among the telephone companies it supplies, 3Com, a maker of telecommunications and data network equipment, said today that its per-share loss for the second quarter would be greater than expected. After the announcement, which came after the market closed, the stock's price plunged in after-hours trading, to $9.75 from $13.38. The shares had risen 44 cents earlier.
docs.snippet: Asserting it had been battered by turmoil among the telephone companies it supplies, 3Com, a maker of telecommunications and data network equipment, said today that its per-share loss for the second quarter would be greater than expected.    After...

docs.abstract: French court rules that Yahoo must prevent World Wide Web users in France from visiting its auction sites that sell Nazi memorabilia, or face heavy fines for each day it does not comply; court-appointed panel of experts disputes Yahoo's contention that such steps are technically not feasible; decision of court is major victory for Jewish groups in France and for international organization battling racism (M)

headline.main: French Uphold Ruling Against Yahoo on Nazi Sites

docs.lead_paragraph: Upholding a verdict that has unsettled the Internet industry in France for the last seven months, a court here ruled today that Yahoo must prevent World Wide Web users in France from visiting its auction sites that sell Nazi memorabilia, or face heavy fines for each day that it did not comply. Lawyers for Yahoo, who have argued that such steps are technically not feasible, said they would study ways to appeal the decision.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: NAZI POLICIES TOWARD JEWS AND MINORITIES

docs.abstract: Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers decides on seven new domains: .info, .biz, .pro, .name, .museum, .aero and .coop; photo (M)

headline.main: 7 New Domains Are Chosen To Join the Popular .com

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to expand the virtual real estate of the Internet, the board that oversees the Internet's addressing system decided today on seven new domains to compete with the popular .com. The board, the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, known as Icann, selected .info and .biz for general use and .pro for professionals. Also added were .name for personal Web sites, .museum for museums, .aero for airline groups and .coop for business cooperatives.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: INTERNET CORP FOR ASSIGNED NAMES AND NUMBERS

docs.abstract: Transmeta Corp will make its debut on Nasdaq with initial public offering that raises $273 million; company presold 13 million shares at $21 apiece, well above estimated range of $16 to $18 (M)

headline.main: Microprocessor Maker's Public Offering Raises $273 Million

docs.lead_paragraph: The Transmeta Corporation will make its debut on the Nasdaq Tuesday with an initial public offering that raised $273 million today, in what some analysts are calling the tepid I.P.O. market's first sign of life in more than a month. Transmeta, whose Crusoe microprocessor uses less power than any other chip on the market, presold 13 million shares at $21 apiece, well above the estimated range of $16 to $18.

docs.abstract: Priceline.com continues its downward slide, laying off 87 employees, or 16 percent of its work force, as it discloses plunge in airline ticket sales in October and resignation of its chief financial officer, Heidi G Miller; company says revenue for third quarter was $341 million, up from $152 million for period last year; including all charges, company lost $199 million in quarter; Priceline says it will take $9 million charge for cutting strike price on warrants that Delta Air Lines holds on its shares; change could result in bonanza for Delta if Priceline stock rises even a few dollars (M)

headline.main: Priceline Reduces Staff 16% And Reports a Sales Plunge

docs.lead_paragraph: Priceline.com continued its downward slide yesterday, laying off 87 employees, or 16 percent of its work force, as it disclosed that its airline ticket sales plunged in October and its chief financial officer had quit. The layoffs will force Priceline to take a one-time charge in the fourth quarter, the company said. It would not predict the size of the charge or its overall sales or profits for the quarter.

docs.abstract: Investors flee already beaten down stock and bonds of Globalstar Telecommunications Ltd, Bermuda-based operationg arm of Globalstar LLC, after it reports disappointing third-quarter earnings; many investors are even more unnerved when Bernard L Schwartz, chairman and chief executive of Loral Space and Communications, Globalstar's largest shareholder, is quoted as saying that Loral will not make any further sacrifices to bail out $4.3 billion venture; Loral, which has 38 percent stake in Globalstar, has sunk more than $1 billion into system and will soon put another $500 million to cover loans it guaranteed; Schwartz argues that his remarks were misinterpreted and that he believes Globalstar is on road to success; Globalstar reports net loss for third quarter of $219 million; net revenue was $1,190,000, versus $708,000 in prior quarter; photo (M)

headline.main: Rising Woes Cast Doubt on Globalstar Survival

docs.lead_paragraph: The odds against Globalstar avoiding the path to bankruptcy court taken last year by two other companies that sought to provide satellite phone service -- Iridium L.L.C. and ICO Global Communications -- got a little steeper yesterday. Investors fled the already beaten down stock and bonds of Globalstar Telecommunications Ltd., the Bermuda-based operating arm of Globalstar L.L.C., after it reported disappointing third-quarter earnings. The earnings were bad enough, but many investors were even more unnerved when Bernard L. Schwartz, chairman and chief executive of Loral Space and Communications, Globalstar's largest shareholder, was quoted as saying that Loral would not make any further sacrifices to bail out the $4.3 billion venture.
